title-group.article-title: Somatic mutant selection is altered by prior NOTCH1 mutation in aging esophageal epithelium

abstract.p: In cancer evolution, genome alterations often occur in a specific order, implying selection depends on the prior clonal genotype1–3. It is unknown if similar constraints operate in normal epithelia. Here, we mapped mutations in normal mid-esophagus of aged UK subjects. Mutant NOTCH1 clones colonized most of the epithelium by age 60 and the tissue became saturated with mutants under strong competitive selection by age 70. Compared to samples that were mostly NOTCH1 wildtype, samples predominantly mutant for NOTCH1 showed weaker selection of mutant TP53 and increased selection of NOTCH2 mutants. In mouse esophagus lacking Notch1 we observed strong selection of mutant Notch2, not seen in wild type epithelium. In aging esophagus, the first driver mutation may change the trajectory of subsequent somatic evolution by altering mutational selection and by restricting space available for the expansion of other mutant clones.

body.p: There is strong evidence that the order in which somatic genome alterations occur is critical in carcinogenesis1. In the squamous esophagus, for example, loss of both alleles of TP53 is an initiating event, being found from the earliest lesions to esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC)4,5. Conversely, NOTCH1 mutations are more common in normal epithelium than ESCC, and in mice Notch1 mutation reduces tumor growth6.

The esophagus is an ideal tissue in which to investigate if ‘order matters’ for somatic mutations in a normal epithelial context. Esophageal epithelium is progressively colonized over decades by mutant clones under strong positive selection, which compete for the limited space available7–9. We began our investigation by mapping the mutational landscape of a large area of epithelium in older subjects.

We employed three DNA sequencing methods to map the mutational landscape in normal mid-esophageal epithelium. We analysed 2,856 samples by combining results from 22 transplant donors aged up to 79 years with 9 previously sequenced subjects (Fig. 1, Supplementary Table 1)7. All donors had no history of cancer or oesophageal disease. Analysis of germline single-nucleotide polymorphisms altering the risk of developing ESCC found the donors were genetically representative of the UK population (Methods, Supplementary Table 2)10–14.

The epithelium was dissected into a gridded array of rectangular samples each 2 mm2 in area (Fig. 1). A total 2,405 two mm2 samples were analysed (total area 48.1cm2). In addition, a further 451 samples were collected using a circular micro biopsy punch (area=0.05 mm2) in a spaced array (Fig. 1)8.

We first estimated the genome-wide mutation burden in all 31 donors using a modified form of duplex sequencing (NanoSeq), an accurate single molecule assay15. Substitution burdens ranged from 0.17-0.59 mutations/megabase (Supplementary Table 3). A general linear model (ANCOVA) suggested that substitution burden increased with both donor age (p=5.71e-08) and smoking status (p= 8.23e-04). Having smoked increased oesophageal mutational burden by the equivalent of about 14 years of age compared to never smoking (Extended data Fig. 1a).

Mutational signature analysis revealed three age correlated single base signatures SBS1, 5 and 40 (https://cancer.sanger.ac.uk/signatures/sbs)16 (Extended Data Fig. 1b, Supplementary Table 3). There was no variation in single base mutational signatures associated with smoking status, consistent with a study of over 500 ESCC genomes, which identified a tobacco-associated SBS signature in only 8% of tumors in smokers17.

Next, we mapped the mutations across 2 mm2 samples using targeted sequencing (median coverage 855x, range 219-1454x) (Methods, Supplementary Table 4). After merging clones spanning adjacent samples 20,589 independent mutations were identified (Supplementary Table 5). In addition, 451 0.05 mm2 samples were collected in regularly spaced arrays from the epithelium of 7 donors aged 61-75 years (Fig. 1) and subjected to targeted sequencing of 324 cancer associated genes (Supplementary Table 1, Methods)18. 1406 independent mutations were identified after merging mutants spanning adjacent samples (Supplementary Tables 6,7).

The ratio of protein altering to synonymous mutations (dN/dS) for each gene indicates whether mutants are under selection7,19. dN/dS analysis revealed a total of 17 mutant genes under positive selection for missense, protein truncating and indel mutations in 2 mm2 and 0.05 mm2 samples (dNdScv, q<0.01, Extended data Fig.2a-b, Supplementary Table 8). Of these, mutant EPHA2 and EEF1A1 have not been reported to drive clonal expansion in normal esophagus. EPHA2 encodes a receptor for EPH ligands, and promotes keratinocyte differentiation, consistent with mutants driving clonal expansion20. Mutants of EEF1A1, which has functions beyond protein synthesis, drive clonal expansion in the epidermis 21,22.

We used data from the 2 mm2 samples to generate spatial maps summarising colonization by mutant clones in different age groups (Fig. 2a, Methods). The area of mutant epithelium rose progressively, and above age 70 the tissue became saturated with mutant clones under strong positive selection (Fig. 2b). The most prevalent selected mutant gene was NOTCH1, which occupied the majority of wild type epithelium by age 60 and colonized a median of 80% of epithelium in the over 70s (Fig. 2c)6–8. Notably, the median proportion of epithelium colonized by mutant TP53 increased from under 5% in those under 60 to 19% for donors over 70 (Fig. 2d, Supplementary Table 9).

To investigate clonal genome alterations, we performed whole genome sequencing (WGS) on forty 2 mm2 and 173 0.05 mm2 samples in which a mutation was present in 50% or more cells (Supplementary Tables 1, 10–14). Phylogenetic analysis revealed the 0.05 mm2 samples derived from 63 independent clones (Supplementary Table 11). The median mutational burden of 0.05 mm2 samples was 1850 single base substitutions per genome (range 202-3011). Mutational signature analysis was consistent with NanoSeq, except in three donors in whom signature 16, associated with alcohol, was detected (Supplementary Table 13).

Figure 3a summarises data from WGS of sixteen 0.05 mm2 samples from eight clones in a 75-year-old male never smoker, each carrying at least one positively selected mutation. Three clones had a TP53 mutation and one (sample do) had undergone loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at the TP53 locus on chromosome 17p (Supplementary Table 11). Conversely, out of eight NOTCH1 mutant clones there were three occurrences of LOH at the NOTCH1 locus on chromosome 9q (samples ei, eo, and ef). Across all 173 WGS samples we observed only one example of TP53 LOH but 22 occurrences of NOTCH1 LOH, four of which occurred in the absence of a NOTCH1 mutation (Supplementary Table 11). Additional copy number alterations (CNA) were found in only two clones (18p deletion with 20p amplification and Chromosome 7 amplification, Supplementary Table 11).

Genomes of the larger clones in 2 mm2 samples carried between one and three positively selected drivers (Fig. 3b, Supplementary Table 12). The most commonly mutated genes were NOTCH1 (25 samples) and TP53 (11 samples). Biallelic disruption of these genes was observed in 23/25 and 3/11 samples respectively.

We used targeted sequencing data to extend our analysis of CNA at the NOTCH1 and TP53 loci to 393 0.05 mm2 samples (Methods). In samples sequenced by both WGS and targeted sequencing the calls at both loci agreed. 25% (97 of 393) of samples carried CNA at the NOTCH1 locus, but only 0.3% (1 of 393) CNA at the TP53 locus. Of the samples with NOTCH1 CNA, 70% (68 of 97) carried one or more NOTCH1 mutation(s) (Supplementary Table 6). Overall genomes in aging normal esophagus remain genome stable apart from LOH at driver loci.

The most striking observation was the disruption of NOTCH1 across most of the tissue by middle age. We speculated that this may alter the selection of mutations that occur in the subsequent decades of life. To test this, we first compared the number of non-synonymous mutants in samples which were predominantly NOTCH1 mutant (NOTCH1High), i.e. the summed VAF for all NOTCH1 mutant clones exceeded 0.4 (Methods) with the remaining NOTCH1Low samples. In both 0.5 mm2 and 2 mm2 NOTCH1High samples, selection of mutant NOTCH2 was increased and selection of mutant TP53 mutants decreased compared with the corresponding NOTCH1Low samples, while other positively selected mutants were unchanged (Fig. 4a-b). Furthermore, the VAF of NOTCH2 mutations was increased in 2 mm2 NOTCH1High samples across all age groups (Fig. 4c). TP53 mutant clones had a smaller VAF in NOTCH1High samples in donors aged over 70 (Fig 4d). These results suggests that selection may be altered following NOTCH1 mutation.

To challenge this hypothesis, we turned to a mouse model. Mouse esophagus differs from human in having a single, basal, proliferative cell layer, and fewer suprabasal cell layers which undergo keratinized differentiation23,24. However, exposure to mutagens generates a mutational landscape resembling that of aging human esophagus9,25, in which mutant Notch1 and p53 drive clonal expansion6,26.

Notch1 null esophageal epithelium was generated in YFPCreNotch1flox/flox mice, a triple transgenic strain carrying a drug inducible Cre allele, and two conditional alleles, a neutral EYFP reporter in the Rosa26 locus and a conditional Notch1 allele (Fig. 5a, Methods)6. Cre was induced and animals aged, after which the epithelium was divided into a gridded array of 2 mm2 samples and subjected to targeted sequencing for Notch pathway and cancer genes (Supplementary Table 16)6. Uninduced littermates with a Notch1 wild type esophagus were used as controls. The average sequencing depth was 365x in control samples and 339x in Notch1-/- samples. The sequencing depth of exon1 of Notch1, which is deleted by Cre recombination, was used to check for recombination in each sample (Extended Data Fig. 3a). Sparse spontaneous mutations were detected in the mouse aged epithelium (44 mutations in 51 Notch1-/- samples and 39 mutations in 50 Notch1+/+ control samples) (Supplementary Tables 17-20). Most nonsynonymous mutations were in Notch1 in Notch1+/+ epithelium (25/35) and in Notch2 in Notch1-/- tissue (35/41) (Fig. 5b). dNdS analysis revealed mutant Notch1 was positively selected in wild type esophagus whereas Notch2 mutants were selected in Notch1 null esophagus, with the selected mutant genes colonizing similar areas of epithelium in their respective strains (Fig 5b-c).

To confirm this result, we aged a second cohort of induced and control mice and immunostained the esophageal epithelium for NOTCH2, finding foci of altered NOTCH2 staining in Notch1-/- but not control esophagi (Fig. 5d-f). Targeted sequencing showed the areas of altered NOTCH2 staining carried clonal nonsynonymous Notch2 mutations (Extended Data Fig 3b-e, Supplementary Tables 20,21). We conclude that prior Notch1 deletion increases selection of Notch2 in aging mouse esophagus, a finding consistent with altered selection seen in mutant NOTCH1High samples in humans.

Overall, our study found the normal esophageal epithelium of the UK becomes saturated with mutants above age 70, the most prevalent of which is mutant NOTCH1. Analysis of clone genomes found only rare (<2%) clones with one or more hallmarks of the ESCC genome such as biallelic TP53 loss, multiple driver mutations and widespread copy number alterations5. The APOBEC mutational signature, prominent in over 90% of ESCC, was not detected17. The absence of multiple ESCC genome changes in normal esophagus, together with the dominance of the anti-oncogenic mutant NOTCH1 seems consistent with the comparatively low incidence of ESCC in the UK.

What is the significance of increased NOTCH2 selection in NOTCH1 mutant epithelium? The proportion of epithelium carrying nonsynonymous NOTCH2 mutants in human esophagus reaches 5.7% in 70–79-year-olds (Fig. 6a). However, NOTCH2 mutations are found in only 2.8% of ESCC (38/1345, https://cancer.sanger.ac.uk/cosmic). The similar prevalence of mutants in normal tissue and cancer argues against NOTCH2 mutants having a major role in promoting transformation and is consistent with the proposition that mutant NOTCH1 protects against transformation.

The observation of decreased selection of mutant TP53 and lower VAF of mutant TP53 clones in NOTCH1High samples above the age of 70 is intriguing. By age 70 the tissue is saturated with mutants (Fig. 2a, b), so in NOTCH1High samples TP53 mutant clones are likely to compete for space with NOTCH1 mutants. The competitive fitness of TP53 mutants is less than mutant NOTCH1 as evidenced by their ability to colonize normal esophagus (Fig. 2 c,d). Furthermore, in transgenic mouse esophagus, it appears that mutagen induced Notch1 mutants may restrict the expansion of p53 mutant clones (Fig 4d)26. Such spatial constraint of mutant TP53 by the fitter mutant NOTCH1 seems a plausible mechanism for our observations.

Mutant selection in the esophagus is a dynamic process in which the competitive fitness required for clone survival increases with age. Colonization by mutant NOTCH1 acts to alter selection in two ways, first by promoting the selection of a seemingly non-oncogenic mutant and secondly by constraining expansion of an oncogenic mutant (Fig. 6b). More generally, future mutant selection may be altered by the current genotype in epithelia, shaping clonal evolution and the likelihood of transformation.

sec.title: Ethical Approval for animal experiments
sec.p: Approval was given by the local ethical review committees at the Wellcome Sanger Institute and conducted according to Home Office project licenses PPL70/7543, P14FED054 and PF4639B40.

sec.title: Ethical approval for human study
sec.p: The study protocol was ethically reviewed and approved by the UK National Research Ethics Service Committee East of England - Cambridge South, Research Ethics Committee protocol reference 15/EE/0152 NRES. Esophageal tissue was obtained from deceased organ donors. Written Informed consent was obtained from the donor’s next of kin.

sec.title: Human samples
sec.p: A sample of mid-esophagus was removed within 60 minutes of circulatory arrest from 22 deceased organ donors at Addenbrooke’s Hospital (Cambridge, UK) and placed in University of Wisconsin (UW) organ preservation solution (Belzer UW® Cold Storage Solution, Bridge to Life, USA). Human esophagus epithelium was isolated and cut into a gridded array of 2 mm2 samples as described 7. DNA was extracted using QIAMP DNA microkit (Qiagen, 56304). Germline samples were collected from flash frozen oesophageal muscle and DNA was extracted as for the epithelial samples.
DNA from a 2 mm2 sample was analyzed by nanorate sequencing (NanoSeq)15. As well as the 22 donors collected in this study, DNA from 9 donors reported in a previous study was also analyzed by NanoSeq.

sec.title: NanoSeq
sec.p: NanoSeq is a method of single DNA molecule sequencing with an error rate less than five per billion base pairs, therefore providing an accurate estimation of genome-wide mutation burden15. Calling mutations from a single molecule of DNA also means that mutation burden estimates are not affected by the clonality of the sample. Nonetheless, to maximise consistency in sampling across donors, 2 mm2 samples were selected for NanoSeq if mutated for NOTCH1 (as determined by targeted sequencing, see below), since this is the most common somatic cell genotype in aged oesophageal epithelium. Substitution counts were corrected for genome-wide trinucleotide contexts and genome-wide burden estimated by dividing by the sequence footprint (Supplementary Table 3).

50ng of DNA from a 2 mm2 grid sample was used for library preparation according to15. Briefly, DNA was digested with mung bean nuclease, A-tailed, repaired and tagged. 0.3fmol of indexed tagged library were sequenced with 14 PCR cycles before quantifying and sequencing on a NovaSeq6000 (Illumina) with 150bp PE reads to give a median 0.9x duplex coverage. 30x coverage whole genome sequence of oesophageal muscle from the same patient was used as the germline control for calling of SNPs and indels. Only samples with verifyBAMID alpha freemix <0.005 were used in downstream analysis. For both SNV and indels, only calls which passed all the defined filters were used https://github.com/cancerit/NanoSeq.

sec.title: Donor Genotyping
sec.p: Donor genotypes were ascertained by whole-genome sequencing of donor muscle. A list of 34 ESCC risk alleles were obtained from the National Human Genome Research Institute-European Bioinformatics Institute GWAS (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas/) and Open Targets (https://genetics.opentargets.org) databases. Associated genes are suggested for each SNP using PheWAS and eQTL data from the Open Targets Genetics database. Risk allele frequencies for Great Britain (GBR), East Asia (EAS) and Africa (AFR) are quoted according to the 1000 Genomes Project Phase 3 to show donors in this study are representative of the UK population in terms of ESCC risk (Supplementary Table 2).

sec.title: 2 mm2 sample sequencing
sec.p: For targeted sequencing of 2 mm2 grid samples 200ng of genomic DNA was fragmented (average size distribution ~ 150bp, LE220, Covaris Inc), purified, libraries prepared (NEBNext Ultra II DNA Library prep Kit, New England Biolabs), and index tags applied (Sanger 168 tag set). Index tagged samples were amplified (6 cycles of PCR, KAPA HiFi kit, KAPA Biosystems), quantified (Accuclear dsDNA Quantitation Solution, Biotium), then pooled together in an equimolar fashion. 9 500ng of pooled material was taken forward for hybridization, capture and enrichment (SureSelect Target enrichment system, Agilent technologies), normalised to ~6nM, and sequenced with 75bp PE reads on HiSeq2500. Samples were sequenced with one of two bait panels. The 74 gene bait panel covered the following genes (ADAM29, ADAMTS18, AJUBA, AKT1, AKT2, APOB, ARID1A, ARID2, AURKA, BAI3, BRAF, CASP8, CCND1, CDH1, CDKN2A, CR2, CREBBP, CUL3, DICER1, EGFR, EPHA2, ERBB2, ERBB3, ERBB4, EZH2, FAT1, FAT4, FBXW7, FGFR1, FGFR2, FGFR3, FLG2, GRIN2A, GRM3, HRAS, IRF6, KCNH5, KEAP1, KMT2A, KMT2C, KMT2D, KRAS, MET, MUC17, NF1, NFE2L2, NOTCH1, NOTCH2, NOTCH3, NOTCH4, NRAS, NSD1, PCED1B, PIK3CA, PLCB1, PPP1R3A, PREX2, PTCH1, PTEN, PTPRT, RB1, RBM10, SALL1, SCN11A, SCN1A, SETD2, SMAD4, SMO, SOX2, SPHKAP, SUFU, TP53, TP63 and TRIOBP.) while the 32 gene bait panel covered a subset of these (ADAM10, AJUBA, ARID1A, ARID2, CCND1, CUL3, DICER1, ERBB4, FAT1, FAT4, FBXW7, HRAS, KMT2C, KMT2D, KRAS, NF1, NFE2L2, NOTCH1, NOTCH2, NOTCH3, NRAS, NSD1, PIK3CA, PREX2, PTCH1, PTEN, RB1, SMAD4, SMO, TP53, TP63, ZNF750)

BAM files were mapped to the human reference genome (GRCh37d5) using BWA-mem (version 0.7.17)27. Duplicate reads were marked using SAMtools (version 1.11)28. Depth of coverage (ca. 900x) was calculated using SAMtools to exclude reads which were: unmapped, not in the primary alignment, failing platform/vendor quality checks or were PCR/Optical duplicates. BEDTools (version 2.23.0) coverage program was then used to calculate the depth of coverage per base across samples29,30. BAM files of samples for nine published donors were then incorporated for all downstream analysis (Supplementary Table 1)7.

For targeted sequencing data, sub-clonal mutation variant calling was made using the deepSNV R package (also commonly referred to as ShearwaterML), version 1.26.1 commit d45c86c, available at https://github.com/gerstung-lab/deepSNV, used in conjunction with R version 3.5.27. Variants were annotated using VAGrENT, https://github.com/cancerit/VAGrENT, version 3.3.331.

Mutations called by ShearwaterML were filtered using the following criteria: ∘
Germline variants called from the same individual were removed from the list of called variants.∘
Adjustment for FDR and mutations demanded support from at least one read from both strands for the mutations identified.∘
Pairs of SNVs on adjacent nucleotides within the same sample are merged into a dinucleotide variant if at least 90% of the mapped DNA reads containing at least one of the SNV pair, contained both SNVs.∘
Identical mutations found in multiple contiguous tissue biopsies are merged and considered as a single clone to prevent duplicate clone counting.
ShearwaterML was run with a normal panel coverage of approximately 42,000x for the 74-gene panel and around 12,000x for the 32-gene panel.

sec.title: 0.05 mm2 sample sequencing
sec.p: 0.05 mm2 samples were collected with circular biopsy punch (0.25 mm diameter, Stoelting Europe), in a rectangular array, with approximately a punch diameter between each sample. DNA was extracted using the Arcturus picopure kit (ThermoFisher).

Shearing and library prep was performed using the NEBNext®Ultra™ II Fragmentase System. DNA was hybridised using a bait panel described previously32 which contains many cancer driver genes. Material was subjected to 12 PCR cycles (Initial denaturation: 95C 5mins, 98C 30sec, 65C 30sec, 72C 2mins 12 cycles, 72C 10mins). Variants were called using the CaVEMan (version 1.15.1), http://cancerit.github.io/CaVEMan/, and cgpPindel (version 3.7.0), http://cancerit.github.io/cgpPindel, algorithms33,34. For SNVs CaVEMan was run with the major copy number set to 10 and the minor copy number set to 2. Only SNVs which passed all CaVEMan filters were kept.

sec.title: Whole Genome Sequencing
sec.p: 2 mm2 and 0.05 mm2 samples were selected for WGS if targeted sequencing determined that at least half the tissue was dominated by a single clone. Sequences were aligned to the human reference genome (GRCh37d5) using BWA-MEM27. Single-base substitutions were called against a donor’s matched germline sample using CaVEMan33. Mapping artefacts were removed, the median alignment score of reads supporting a variant had to be at least 140 and the number of clipped reads equal to zero. In addition, the proportion of mutant reads present in the matched sample also had to be zero. Small (<200 bp) insertions and deletions were called using cgpPindel. Only indels which passed all cgpPindel filters were kept. For 0.05 mm2 samples, a large excess of single base pair insertions at homopolymers of length five or more were removed, an artefact caused by PCR amplification of low-input DNA concentrations. Telomere lengths were estimated using the Telomerecat software package (version 4.0.2, https://github.com/cancerit/telomerecat/)35. Telomere length is given as a median of all chromosomes for all cells in that sample.

sec.title: Phylogeny Construction
sec.p: A pile-up of quality reads was constructed, and the number of mutant and wildtype reads counted for every locus that had a mutation called in any sample of a donor. Reads with a mapping quality of at least 30 and bases with a base quality of at least 25 were used. Mutations with a VAF < 0.2 were assigned a genotype of 0 and those with a VAF >= 0.3 a genotype of 1. All other mutations were set a genotype of NA (not applicable) for the purposes of phylogeny construction. Maximum parsimony trees were drawn for each donor after 1000 iterations with MPBoot36. Substitutions in mutant genes under selection were assigned to each branch of a phylogeny. Copy number aberrations were manually assigned to each branch where present.

sec.title: Mutational signature analysis
sec.p: Mutational spectra and signatures are described using the notation employed by the PCAWG Mutational Signatures working group37. COSMIC signature definitions (v3.2) (https://cancer.sanger.ac.uk/signatures/sbs/) were used for Single Base Substitutions (SBS), Double base Substitutions (DBS) and Indel signature classification. Using SigProfiler packages MatrixGenerator (v1.2.12), Extractor (v1.1.12), Assignment (v0.0.13), Plotting (1.2.2). The frequency of mutations within each trinucleotide context was calculated using SigProfiler within the SBS28837.

The maximum-likelihood implementation dNdScv (v0.0.1.0, https://github.com/im3sanger/dndscv) was used to identify genes under positive selection. dNdScv estimates the ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous mutations across genes, adjusting for sequence composition and mutational spectrum. dN/dS values significantly greater than 1 indicate positive selection.
The proportion of mutant epithelium was calculated from mutant VAFs as described7,38.

sec.title: Copy number calling
sec.p: Copy number calling on WGS was inferred with ASCATNGS (https://github.com/cancerit/ascatNgs), using oesophageal muscle from the same patient as a germline control34. For inferring copy number from the 0.05 mm2 punch samples sequenced with a targeted bait panel ASCAT (v3.1.0) was used. Regions were restricted to the NOTCH1 and TP53 loci, only SNPS within these regions were identified in the normal samples. Allele counts were generated for SNP positions from these normal samples allowing calling for both 0.05 mm2 punch and germline samples. These were used to derive LogR values and BAF values used to generate segment calls of allele-specific copy number. https://github.com/VanLoo-lab/ascat39.

sec.title: Animals and strains
sec.p: Animals were 10 to 16 weeks old at the start of the experiments. Mice were housed in Specific and Opportunistic Pathogen Free unit with a 12-hour light/12-hour dark cycle. Lights were switched off at 19:30 and there was no twilight period. Ambient temperature was 21 ± 2 °C, and humidity 55 ± 10%. Mice were kept at 3–5 mice per cage, in cages measuring 365 mm × 207 mm × 140 mm (length × width × height), with a floor area, of 530 cm2. Individually ventilated caging (Tecniplast, Sealsafe 1284L) with 60 air changes/ hour was used. As well as Aspen bedding substrate, environmental enrichment with Nestlets, a cardboard tunnel and chew blocks was provided. Water and standard chow diet were provided ad libitum. Experiments were carried out with male and female animals and no sex specific differences were observed. Animals were randomly assigned to experimental groups.

YFPCreNotch1 triple mutant mice6 were generated by crossing B6.129X1-Notch1tm2Rko/GridJ mice purchased from the Jackson Laboratory with Rosa26floxedYFP and AhCreERT mice 23,40,41. In these animals, Cre mediated recombination is induced by treatment with β-Naphthoflavone and Tamoxifen. An enhanced yellow fluorescent (EYFP) reporter is expressed from the Rosa 26 locus after Cre mediated excision of a LoxP flanked ‘stop’ cassette. Exon1 of Notch1 is flanked by LoxP sequences so that Cre mediated recombination blocks Notch1 expression.

sec.title: Aging experiments
sec.p: YFPCreNotch1flox/flox mice aged between 10-16 weeks-old were injected intraperitoneally (i.p.) with β-Naphthoflavone (MP Biomedicals, catalog no.156738) at 80 mg.kg-1 and tamoxifen (Sigma Aldrich, catalog no. N3633) at 0.25mg and collected at up to 78 weeks old. Notch1+/+ or non-induced YFPCreNotch1flox/flox mice were used as wild type controls.

sec.title: Whole-mount preparation and immunostaining of mouse esophagus
sec.p: Mouse esophagus was opened longitudinally before removing the underlying muscle layer with forceps. Esophageal tissue, comprising mucosa and submucosa, was incubated for 2h15 to 3 hours in 5 mM Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) at 37 °C before peeling away the epithelium. The flattened epithelium was fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 75 minutes at room temperature under agitation then washed and stored in PBS at 4 °C 9. All subsequent steps were performed at room temperature. Tissues were incubated in staining buffer for a one-hour blockage (10% donkey serum, 0.5% bovine serum albumin, 0.5% Triton X-100, 0.25% fish skin gelatin in PHEM). This step was followed by overnight incubation with primary antibodies in staining buffer, three 30 min washes in 0.2% Tween-20 PHEM, and a 3 hour-long incubation with secondary antibodies in staining buffer (Supplementary Table 23). After washes in PHEM, tissues were incubated for 1h in 0.5 μM Sytox™ Blue nuclei counterstain (Biolegend, catalog no. 425305) and mounted on slides using Vectashield media (Vector Laboratories, catalog no. H-1000).

sec.title: Sequencing of aged esophageal epithelial wholemounts
sec.p: Whole mounts from aged, induced YFPCreNotch1flox/flox or control mice were flattened and dissected into a grid of 2 mm2 contiguous biopsies. DNA extraction was performed using the QIAMP DNA microkit (Qiagen, catalog no. 56304) following the manufacturer’s instructions. Each sample was then subject to targeted sequencing.

sec.title: Identification and sequencing Notch2 mutant clones by immunostaining
sec.p: We used a similar approach to that described for identifying Notch1 mutant clones in a previous study6. Whole mounted epithelium was stained for NOTCH2, EYFP (using an anti-GFP antibody) and Sytox™ Blue and imaged by confocal microscopy. Large, ovoid areas with either low intensity or null NOTCH2 staining suggested the presence of Notch2 mutant clones (Extended data Fig. 3a). Similarly, large and ovoid areas with non-nuclear localization of the NOTCH2 protein also suggested the presence of Notch2 mutations that would alter the cleavage or nuclear translocation of NICD2, as the EDTA incubation at 37°C used to prepare the wholemounts activates NOTCH2 cleavage42. Finally, YFP staining helped identifying putative mutant clones, appearing as large and ovoid areas devoid or fully stained with YFP (Extended data Fig. 3b).

Putative clones with altered NOTCH2 staining were sampled under a Fluorescent Stereo Microscope Leica M165 FC (Leica) using 0.25 mm diameter punch (Stoelting, catalog no. 57391). DNA extraction was performed using Arcturus® PicoPure® DNA extraction kit (Applied Biosystems, catalog no. 11815-00) following the manufacturer’s instructions. Targeted sequencing was then performed on each sample.

sec.title: Targeted Sequencing of mouse samples
sec.p: After multiplexing, samples were sequenced on Illumina HiSeq 2000 sequencer using paired-end 75-base pair (bp) reads. An Agilent SureSelect custom bait capture kit comprising 73 cancer related and Notch pathway related genes (baitset_3181471_Covered.bed, Supplementary Table 16) was used6.
For 2 mm2 samples the average depth of coverage across all genes was: Notch1+/+: 365x; Notch1-/-: 339x.
For 0.05 mm2 samples the average depth of coverage across all genes was 228x.

Paired-end reads were aligned to the GRCm38 reference mouse genome with BWA-MEM (v.0.7.17, https://github.com/lh3/bwa)27 with optical and PCR duplicates marked using Biobambam2 (v.2.0.86, https://github.com/gt1/biobambam2).

Mutations in 0.05 mm2 samples from aged YFPCreNotch1-/- mice were analysed with CaVEMan (version 1.13.14) and with cgpPindel (version 3.3.0)34 for insertions and deletions. Sequence variants were annotated with VAGrENT (version 3.3.3)33,43.

Mutations in 2 mm2 samples were also called with deepSNV (v1.26.1), https://github.com/gerstung-lab/deepSNV). The total coverage provided by the references used for the mouse bait kit was 22885x in a total of 34 germline samples.

In a gridded array of samples, some mutations can span between several adjacent biopsies. To prevent counting them multiple times and obtain accurate estimates of clone sizes and number, mutations extending over two or more biopsies were merged as individual calls14,27.
Selection was determined using dNdScv (v0.0.1.0) commit c3437e.

The proportion of cells carrying a mutation within each sample was calculated from the fraction of cells carrying a mutation within the sample, as described previously7,38. The lower (=VAF) and upper (=2xVAF) bound estimates of the percentage of epithelium covered by clones carrying non-synonymous mutations in each gene was then calculated. The proportion of mutant epithelium was derived from mean of summed VAF (capped at 1.0) of all samples in the esophagus.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data in graphs are shown as mean values ± standard error of the mean (SEM) unless otherwise stated. In general, P values <0.05 were considered statistically significant, but for dN/dS ratios calcuated by dNdScv, a global q<0.01 was considered statistically significant. All significance tests were 2 tailed. Each mouse experiment was performed using multiple biological replicates. The numbers of experimental replicates are given in figure legends and Supplementary tables. Statistical tests described in figure legends were performed using GraphPad Prism software 8.3.1 and Python package SciPy 1.7.3 (https://scipy.org/citing-scipy/). No statistical method was used to predetermine sample size. Animals of the relevant genotype were allocated to experimental groups at random.

caption.title: NOTCH1 mutation alters selection and constrains mutant TP53
caption.p: a. Proportion of NOTCH2 mutant epithelium with age. Each dot is a donor, boxes indicate median and quartiles, bars range. b. Summary. New mutations accumulate at a constant rate. The area of mutant epithelium is determined by fitness of mutant genes under positive selection. Mutant NOTCH1Low samples accumulate new mutations at the same rate as mutant NOTCH1High samples. The area of mutant epithelium is predominantly determined by competitive fitness of expanding mutant clones. In NOTCH1Low samples, TP53 mutant expansion is unconstrained, whereas by age 70, the fitter NOTCH1 mutant clones constrict TP53 mutant clone growth. NOTCH2 mutants are selected preferentially within NOTCH1 mutant epithelium.
